Later comment: Information calls, air for tires, and water fountains are among the free services to disappear and be replaced by pay walls that levy a charge. The sophisticated revenue models of companies (defense first, then health care) long ago hit on how to rake in profits from government: provide a service or product that is a required line item in the budget. Price becomes infinitely elastic.

That model was late coming to education. A limited number of reliable tests (the Stanford Achievement Test, when I was a student!) held the market for decades. But with new regulation, national standards and state curriculums that require test assessments, opportunity loomed. As a 5th grader teacher and blogger described the transition: “my style of teaching goes back to a time that was way before the attack of the standardized tests. Try as I might, I can’t quite grasp the concept of frequent, repetitive testing. I don’t quite have the mental agility to test, teach, retest, teach again, retest and give a score. I’m sort of stuck in the ancient and outdated world of “Learning how to think.” I can’t keep up.”

The accountants with enterprise software can. Those retests measure scores but mean dollars. The acceleration of public education outsourcing is taking place as tuition fees at select NYC preschools are $40,000 annually. ($25,000 is a bargain! NYT, 01/27/12.)

Employees of contractors serve the contractor and have no clout and are paid less because they are needed to do less and to a lower standard.

The civil servant, often unionized, has a career and owes his or her duty to the public. A civil service teacher is more qualified, more professional, works harder, has rights in the workplace and professional input and a career path to a life long career.

Every public dollar spent to public education goes to educating children and providing a physical plant in which to educate children. Privatized education results in profits. That comes from taxpayer money intended to educate their children only some of which goes for that purpose. The contractor takes a cut, delivers only what minimum performance requires with personnel who could not qualify for a civil service professional, permenant teaching position.

In our system, as much as the corporatists deny it, the government, where us it is elected democratically and not corrupted by monied interests, is the people and public education is education of the people's children by the people's own servants and not by profit making corporations. Yes, yes, and yes again. It makes no sense to have one (wealthy) school district providing exceptional opportunities to its students, due to funding through property taxes, while 30 miles down the road at a rural school district the students receive a bare-bones education because the property tax base is low.

The neighborhood or zip code of a child's family shouldn't determine quality of education. I'm familiar with this because our family lived it. Fortunately, we had the means to move. Unfortunately,the majority of children don't live in families who can. I think about those kids every day and how it is that income disparity rules who will- and won't flourish- in our country.

We need to wake up and get real. As it currently stands, our public education system benefits the wealthy and with the increasing use of for-profit companies inserting their $ticky finger$ in to the mix, well, we'll end up with a system skewed even further toward a two tier system. The wealthy don't "need" public education becasue they can afford to send their kids to private schools.

Of course, suggesting that we nationalize our educational system will be met with cries of "socialism" or "communism."

"Of course, suggesting that we nationalize our educational system will be met with cries of "socialism" or "communism.""

Clare, we need to remind people that all things related to common good usually are named "social" something or other. You know, like the "social contract." Nothing is evil or bad until we make it so. We need public education and we need public healthcare. There is no getting around that.

We need to nationalize our education system. It needs to be run from Washington - not the counties, PTAs, boardrooms, educational software makers, coal mine owners, etc. What is going on is a disgrace and the pineapple question is just the cherry on top. Just today, Tennessee legislators began considering a bill that would require kindergarten entrants to take a maturity test. I guess, instead of cutting an already bare bones budget, they've opted to just cut the kids out. Kids need to be engaged, given tools for critical thought and nourished intellectually. Actual food would be good too. All too many kids are hungry, even in areas where hunger wasn't a problem before the recession. We already know that a hungry child doesn't learn well. The right wing is even opposed to feeding kids in school. As for education, the things that fuel a child's imagination and thirst for knowledge are being cut right and left, with arts and other programs being discontinued and hours of instruction cut. What our kids are being taught is often decided by politicians and business people who have some interest to fulfill. It's a crying shame.

We have a National Academy of Science. We have some great universities. Let's put them to good use and in charge of rewriting our education system before it's too late.

I've read that investment clubs do not necessarily show good results for their members. May be that group think can influence members in negative directions.

Also studies of mutual funds show that consistent positive results over time are very rare. Also that financial experts who devote their lives to studying investing cannot predict the market over time. So dumping retirement investing decisions into the hands of the average individual is crazy. Even if you do make money, the question is when to get out, or get in. Brilliant financial analysts don't know for sure. You have to get out of the market many years before you will need that money.

The financial press has made millions selling investing advice to the masses who never had a tradition of investing. In past generations, the average person didn't even read this stuff--now it's all consuming. I guess it's had some good effect giving basic common sense advice. But the public is powerless against the lawless, unregulated financial industry. How long will we keep get zilch interest on our savings? That's the big question.

I am one of the lucky ones who retired with a traditional defined pension plan, and a 401K to go with it. and the day I retired, it put my 401K into a self directed IRA with a major brokerage. But I did several things before I retired. I joined the investment club at work, I studied the market and how it works, and I put the full amount into the 401K at the time.

In the meantime the company no longer offered defined benefit plans to the new hires. They put in a defined contribution plan. Our plan was one of the best in the business world, but the company had been bought by another owner and they were doing everything they could to cut costs, even though the original plan was fully funded.

Even if you do have something like $250K when you retire, that is not enough to make up for lost wages. If you retire at 65 and live to 85, you can only take out $12.5K a year for 20 years. If you get $1600 SS after your medicare payments, that only gives you $31,700 a year income. If you are a good investor, you can get 5% on overage in dividends and interest. That is only $1250 a year in income.

The other big mistake people made in 2008 was to sell. They looked at their accounts and it looked like they were losing money. You do not lose until you sell and if you have good investments, the income continues. You really need something like $800K just to have $60K a year in income. It takes discipline and a strong heart to hang on when your account goes down for a period.

As a student, I have seen little improvement in the past few years regarding the cost of education and cost of student loans. Aside from the numbers aspect of this column, I liked the inclusion of the comment from Senator Mitch McConnell where he said 'Mr. Obama was trying to manufacture an issue and that his campus speeches were intended to distract from economic policies that have made it harder for young people to get job'.

I agree with this quote, the media and the timing of release of comments have made speeches seem like more of a competition of emotional appeal, not just a problem with money. As a current undergrad, I am concerned with the current financial burden that loans have caused, but I am even more concerned with the fact that after I graduate with my hard-earned and hard-paid-for degree, I will have no job prospects to help pay my debt off.

The media should stop reporting the emotional aspects of speeches and report the hard numbers, that's what's important to voters.
